citeinfo.title: Historical Annual First Bloom Index, Contiguous United States, 2016 - Previous Year
USA National Phenology Network, Gridded Data Product Suite

descript.abstract: Historical values for the Extended Spring Index (SI-x) of First Bloom. Each pixel is assigned a day of year value for the First Bloom Index. The Extended Spring Indices are mathematical models that predict the "start of spring" (timing of leaf out or bloom for species active in early spring) at a particular location. This model was constructed using historical observations of the timing of first bloom in a cloned lilac cultivar (S. x chinensis 'Red Rothomagensis') and two cloned honeysuckle cultivars (Lonicera tatarica 'Arnold Red' and L. korolkowii 'Zabelii'). Primary inputs to the model are temperature events, beginning January 1 of each year. Layers are available for each year from 2016 onward. Input temperature data based on NOAA National Centers for Environmental Prediction (NCEP) Unrestricted Mesoscale Analysis (URMA) Products.
descript.purpose: The Extended Spring Indices have been used as an indicator of climate change by both the Environmental Protection Agency and the National Climate Assessment. The historical values of first leaf and first bloom support understanding of spatial patterns in the timing of spring, as well as short-term forecasts to support resource management.

procstep.procdesc: NCEP URMA data (hourly temperatures) are retrieved on a 24-hour cycle over the course of the year.
Spring Index values are calculated across the raster each day of the year using above mentioned climate data.
After day 250 is complete, and the Spring Index values for the raster are no longer subject to change, then the final raster is archived as a data layer of this set.
